===Etymology 1===
{{ja-kanjitab|もり|yomi=k}}
The {{m|ja|連用形|tr=ren'yōkei||continuative or stem form}} of verb {{m|ja|守る|tr=moru||to protect, to watch over}}. Also spelled with the [[okurigana]] {{ja-l|り}}.

====Pronunciation====
{{ja-pron|yomi=k|もり|acc=1|acc_ref=DJR}}

====Alternative forms====
* {{ja-l|守り}}

====Noun====
{{ja-noun|もり}}

# a [[watchman]], a [[keeper]] {{gloss|as of a lighthouse}}, a [[caretaker]]
# a [[nursemaid]], a [[babysitter]]

===Etymology 2===
{{ja-kanjitab|まもる|yomi=k}}
From verb {{m|ja|守る|tr=mamoru||to protect}}.

====Pronunciation====
{{ja-pron|yomi=k|まもる}}

====Proper noun====
{{ja-pos|proper|まもる}}

# {{given name|lang=ja|sort=まもる|male}}

===Etymology 3===
{{ja-kanjitab|まもり|yomi=k}}
The {{m|ja|連用形|tr=ren'yōkei||continuative or stem form}} of verb {{m|ja|守る|tr=mamoru||to protect}}. Also spelled with the [[okurigana]] {{ja-l|り}}.

====Pronunciation====
{{ja-pron|yomi=k|まもり}}

====Alternative forms====
* {{ja-l|守り}}

====Noun====
{{ja-noun|まもり}}

# standing [[watch]], standing [[guard]]
# a [[watchman]], a [[guard]] {{gloss|especially at a [[castle]] or [[fort]]}}
# [[divine]] [[protection]] from [[misfortune]]
# a [[god]] or [[spirit]] providing such protection
# a [[ward]], [[charm]], [[talisman]], or other item providing divine protection
# short for {{l|ja|守り刀}}, {{m|ja|守刀|tr=mamorigatana||protection sword|pos=sword always kept at one's side for personal protection}}
# a [[seal]] or [[coat of arms]] using a {{m|ja|守り札|tr=mamorifuda||charm tag}}, {{m|ja|守り袋|tr=mamoribukuro||charm bag}}, or similar charm for the design

* {{sense|divine protector}} {{ja-r|守り神|まもりがみ}}; {{ja-r|守護神|しゅごしん}}

===Etymology 6===
{{ja-kanjitab|しゅ|yomi=o}}
From {{etyl|ltc|ja|sort=しゅ}}.

====Pronunciation====
{{ja-pron|yomi=goon|しゅ|acc=1|acc_ref=DJR}}

====Noun====
{{ja-noun|しゅ}}

# {{lb|ja|sort=しゅ|archaic}} used when listing an official's titles when there are two or more (compare English {{m|en|cum}})
# short for {{m|ja|守護|tr=shugo||protection, protector}}
# {{lb|ja|sort=しゅ|archaic}} short for {{m|ja|国守|tr=kokushu||head administrator of a ''kuni'' in the old {{w|Ritsuryō}} system}}

===Etymology 7===
{{ja-kanjitab|かみ|yomi=k}}
From the sense of being ''above'' in rank and status. Essentially of the same meaning as {{m|ja|上|tr=kami||above}}, but spelled {{lang|ja|守}} to convey a sense of “[[watch]]ing” or “[[oversee]]ing”.  This spelling is an example of [[熟字訓#Japanese|jukujikun]] or [[ateji]] used for the [[meaning]].

====Pronunciation====
{{ja-pron|yomi=k|かみ}}

====Alternative forms====
* {{ja-l|長官}}

====Noun====
{{ja-noun|かみ}}

# {{lb|ja|sort=かみ|archaic}} under the old {{w|Ritsuryō}} system of ancient Japan, the highest of the four ranks of [[civil servant]] staff, and general term for head [[administrator]]s of government departments
# {{lb|ja|sort=かみ|archaic}} in the first year of the new {{w|Meiji era}} government established in 1868, the [[title]] of the seven heads of all government [[bureau]]s except the {{m|ja|総裁局|tr=Sōsai Kyoku||Bureau of the President}}, whose head was titled {{m|ja|総裁|tr=Sōsai||president” or “director general}}

===Etymology 8===
{{ja-kanjitab|こう|yomi=k}}
Alteration of ''kami''.

{{IPAchar|/kami/}} → {{IPAchar|/kamu/}} → {{IPAchar|/kau/}} → {{IPAchar|/kɔː/}} → {{IPAchar|/koː/}}

====Pronunciation====
{{ja-pron|yomi=k|こう}}

====Noun====
{{ja-noun|こう|hhira=かう}}

# {{lb|ja|sort=こう|obsolete}} see ''kami'' above; used in obsolete titles

=====Derived terms=====
The following are all titles in the old {{w|Ritsuryō}} system.
* {{ja-r|守の君|こう の きみ}}
* {{ja-r|守の殿|こう の との}}
* {{ja-r|守の主|こう の ぬし}}
